properties.Name: InsuranceCompanyType
properties.Description:
A means of categorizing or typing Insurers by common characteristics or functions performed.

The specific legal organization of the Insurer dictates the legal entity characteristics that are recorded for the Insurer (ex. public corporation vs. private company).

As Insurers offer additional services and products in deregulated markets, the differences between types of Insurers may be difficult to discern.

Ex:
- Assessment Mutual Insurer
- Fraternal Benefit Society
- Industrial Risk Insurer
- Mutual Insurer
- Private Insurer
- Publicly Traded Insurer
- Reciprocal Insurer
- Reinsurer
- Risk Retention Group
- Self-Insurer
- Stock Insurer

ASSESSMENT MUTUAL INSURER
An insurer that retains the right to assess policyholders additional amounts if premiums are insufficient for operations.   

In some cases, an assessment insurer may not charge a set premium at all but will merely assess participants in the  plan a pro rata share of each claim filed plus expenses.

Assessment mutual companies are identified by the  way in which they charge premiums.

A pure assessment mutual company operates on the  basis of loss sharing by the  group members.
No premium is payable in advance.   Rather each m ember is assessed an individual portion of losses that actually occur.

An advanced premium assessment mutual charges a premium in advance or at the  beginning of the  policy period.   If the  original premiums exceed the  operating expenses and losses, then the  surplus is returned to the  policyholders as dividends.    If total premiums are not enough to meet losses, then additional assessments are levied against the  members.   Normally the  amount of assessment that may be levied is limited by state law or by a provision in the  insurer's bylaws.

FRATERNAL BENEFIT SOCIETY
An insurer that is a fraternal order or lodge writing insurance on an assessment basis or on a legal reserve basis.

Fraternal societies have memberships based on religious, national or ethnic lines.    

To be a fraternal organization, it must be non-profit, have a lodge system that includes ritualistic work and maintain a representative form of government with elected officers.

Fraternal society insurance may be only sold to members of the  society.

Most fraternal organization issue insurance certificates and annuities with the  same provisions found in policies issued by commercial insurers.

INDUSTRIAL RISK INSURER
A consortium of major stock property and casualty insurers formed to write large, highly protected risks.     

This organization was formed in 1975 by the  merger of the  Factory Insurance Association and the  Oil Insurance Association.

MUTUAL INSURER
An incorporated insurer without incorporated capital owned by its policyholders.

Mutual insurers do distribute their earnings to their policyholders in the  form of dividends.

Mutual insurance companies have no stockholders.     It is owned by the  policyholders.

Anyone purchasing insurance from a mutual insurer is both a customer and an owner, with the  right to vote for the  board of director members.    In issuing participating policies paying policy dividends, mutual insurance companies enable their policyholders to share in any company earnings.

Policy dividends are essentially a refund of the  portion of premiums that remains after the  company has set aside the  required reserves and has made deductions for claims and expenses.

Policy dividends may also include a share in the  company's investment, mortality and operating profits.

Stock and mutual companies are frequently known or referred to as 'commercial insurers' because they can write life, health, property and casualty insurance.

PRIVATE INSURER
Private Insures offer many lines of insurance (life insurance, annuities, accident, health, property and casualty).

Companies that write more than one line of insurance are known as multi-line insurers.

RECIPROCAL INSURER
An unincorporated group of individuals ('subscribers') who mutually insure each other by each separately assuming his share of each risk.

Reciprocal insurers are organized on the  basis of the  ownership by the  policyholders.   It is these policyholders themselves who insure the  risks of the  other policyholders.

Each policyholder assumes a share of the  risk brought to the  company by the  others.

Reciprocal insurers are managed by an attorney-in-fact.

REINSURER
A specialized branch of the  insurance industry that insures Insurers.

Reinsurance is a business arrangement by which an insurance company transfers a portion of the  risk it has assumed to another Insurer.   Reinsurance is a means of limiting the  loss that any one Insurer would face should a very large claim become payable.   

The  company transferring the  risk is called the  ceding company.
The  company assuming the  risk is the  reinsurer.

RISK RETENTION GROUP
A risk retention group is a mutual insurance company formed to insure people in the  same or similar business, occupation or professional group (ex, doctors, engineers etc.)

SELF-INSURER
An organization that makes financial preparations to meet pure risks by appropriating funds in advance to meet estimated losses.

STOCK INSURER
A private organization, organized and incorporated under a state's laws for the   intent and purpose of making a profit for stockholders.

Stock Insurers are structured that same as any corporation. 

Stockholders may or may not be policyholders.  

Stock dividends, if declared, are paid to stockholders.   

The   directors and officers are responsible to the   stockholders.

Columns.Name: InsuranceCompanyTypeId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of an insurance company type.

Columns.Name: InsuranceCompanyTypeName
Columns.Description: The name of an insurance company type.

Columns.Name: InsuranceCompanyTypeDescription
Columns.Description: The description of an insurance company type.
